<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 187]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 195, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 264]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 278, 437, 285]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 286, 539, 317]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 336, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 910, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 370, 670, 390]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 400, 608, 420]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 470, 89]]<|/det|>

She notices that five complete wavelengths pass her in 20 s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 515, 413, 533]]<|/det|> What is the frequency of this wave? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 543, 134, 561]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 543, 218, 561]]<|/det|> 0.25Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 543, 303, 561]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 543, 376, 561]]<|/det|> 4.0Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 543, 470, 561]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 543, 537, 561]]<|/det|> 15Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 543, 636, 561]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 543, 715, 561]]<|/det|> 100Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 588, 107, 606]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 601, 606]]<|/det|> A student uses one eye to look at images in a plane mirror. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 612, 760, 644]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 765, 400, 784]]<|/det|> Objects are placed on the line XY. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 795, 677, 814]]<|/det|> Which objects give rise to images that can be seen by the eye at E? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 824, 134, 842]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 824, 316, 842]]<|/det|> P, Q, R, S, T and U <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 853, 134, 871]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 853, 308, 871]]<|/det|> Q, R, S and T only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 880, 134, 898]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 880, 262, 898]]<|/det|> P and U only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 907, 133, 924]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 907, 262, 924]]<|/det|> R and S only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 920, 135]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 335, 107, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 784, 353]]<|/det|>
Microwaves, green light and infrared are three types of electromagnetic radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 863, 383]]<|/det|>
What is their order when listed by wavelength from the shortest wavelength to the longest?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 395, 134, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 395, 460, 413]]<|/det|>
green light \(\rightarrow\) infrared \(\rightarrow\) microwaves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 422, 134, 441]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 422, 460, 440]]<|/det|>
green light \(\rightarrow\) microwaves \(\rightarrow\) infrared

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 450, 134, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 450, 460, 467]]<|/det|>
infrared \(\rightarrow\) green light \(\rightarrow\) microwaves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 476, 133, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 476, 460, 494]]<|/det|>
microwaves \(\rightarrow\) infrared \(\rightarrow\) green light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 520, 107, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 628, 539]]<|/det|>
Which statement correctly compares radio waves and X-rays?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 549, 134, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 549, 759, 567]]<|/det|>
Radio waves have a longer wavelength and a greater speed in a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 133, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 575, 759, 593]]<|/det|>
Radio waves have a longer wavelength and the same speed in a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 133, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 602, 764, 620]]<|/det|>
Radio waves have a shorter wavelength and a greater speed in a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 133, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 628, 767, 645]]<|/det|>
Radio waves have a shorter wavelength and the same speed in a vacuum.

<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 463, 89]]<|/det|>
Why is a fuse used in an electrical circuit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 100, 509, 117]]<|/det|>
so that the current can have only one value

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 127, 494, 144]]<|/det|>
to prevent the current becoming too large

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 152, 490, 170]]<|/det|>
to provide a path to earth if a fault occurs

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 179, 133, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 179, 356, 196]]<|/det|>
to save electrical energy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The coils in two electric motors are identical in size, but motor 1 is observed to spin more quickly than motor 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 579, 135]]<|/det|>
Three suggestions are made to explain this observation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 146, 203, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 146, 888, 165]]<|/det|>
The current in the coil of motor 1 is greater than the current in the coil of motor 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 173, 203, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 173, 880, 191]]<|/det|>
The number of turns on the coil of motor 1 is greater than on the coil of motor 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 198, 767, 217]]<|/det|>
3 The magnets in motor 1 are stronger than the magnets in motor 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 675, 247]]<|/det|>
Which suggestions give a possible explanation for this observation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 256, 134, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 256, 205, 274]]<|/det|>
1 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 256, 298, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 256, 433, 274]]<|/det|>
1 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 256, 473, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 256, 593, 274]]<|/det|>
2 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 256, 636, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 256, 740, 274]]<|/det|>
1, 2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 301, 106, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 727, 320]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes two atoms of different isotopes of an element?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 330, 133, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 330, 727, 348]]<|/det|>
two atoms with the same nucleon number but different proton number

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 133, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 357, 742, 375]]<|/det|>
two atoms with a different nucleon number but the same proton number

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 133, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 384, 742, 401]]<|/det|>
two atoms with the same nucleon number and the same proton number

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 410, 133, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 410, 740, 427]]<|/det|>
two atoms with a different nucleon number and different proton number

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 453, 106, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 453, 510, 471]]<|/det|>
A radioactive source has a half-life of 0.5 hours.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 707, 501]]<|/det|>
A detector near the source shows a reading of 6000 counts per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 512, 428, 530]]<|/det|>
Background radiation can be ignored.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 542, 541, 560]]<|/det|>
What is the reading on the detector 1.5 hours later?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 571, 131, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 571, 344, 588]]<|/det|>
750 counts per second

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 598, 131, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 598, 354, 615]]<|/det|>
1500 counts per second

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 131, 643]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 625, 354, 643]]<|/det|>
2000 counts per second

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 652, 131, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 652, 354, 670]]<|/det|>
3000 counts per second

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 694, 106, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 694, 871, 712]]<|/det|>
Some nuclei are unstable. They emit radiation and change into nuclei of a different element.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 724, 348, 742]]<|/det|>
What is this process called?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 752, 133, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 752, 245, 771]]<|/det|>
convection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 780, 133, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 780, 366, 797]]<|/det|>
electromagnetic induction

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 807, 133, 824]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 807, 301, 824]]<|/det|>
radioactive decay

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 833, 133, 851]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 833, 285, 850]]<|/det|>
the motor effect
